Technology Roadmap for $57,167.00 Restaurant and Catering Industry sponsorship of conferences $22,000.00 other payments $2,286.00 $8,481.53 $2,190.00 $5,785.85 Total $2,286.00 $30,481.53 $2,190.00 $62,952.85 Superannuation: Age Preservation Rules (Question No. 3158) Mr Murphy asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 1 March 2004: (1) Is he aware of the campaign by the Police Federation of Australia to obtain an exemption for Australia’s 50,000 police officers from the superannuation age preservation rules which prevent officers born after 1 July 1964 from accessing their entitlements before they reach 60 years of age? (2) Is he aware that the principal reason for the Federation’s campaign to ensure Australia’s police are entitled to access superannuation from the age of 55 years is the concern that a police officer over the age of 55 years would be less effective and a risk to fellow colleagues when participating in duties which involve violent confrontation with offenders? (3) Can he confirm that members of Australia’s Defence Force can access superannuation benefits before the age of 55 years? (4) Will he review the Government’s superannuation policy so that Australia’s police officers would be able to retire at the age of 55 years with access to superannuation entitlements; if not why not? (1) Yes, I am aware of the campaign. (2) Yes, I am aware that is the principal reason given. (3) Yes, I am aware that members that joined the Defence Force prior to October 1991 can access their benefits prior to 55. New members after that date must wait until preservation age to access their benefits. (4) Under the current law, superannuation benefits can be accessed at any age if the following conditions are met: there has been termination of gainful employment; and the benefits are taken in the form of a non-commutable life pension or annuity; and the fund’s governing rules cater for this type of payment.
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Costello
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:Education: Workers Education Association (Question No. 3221) Ms George asked the Minister for Education, Science and Training, upon notice, on 2 March 2004: (1) Is the Minister aware that when Workers Education Association Illawarra (WA) was awarded the contract to provide English courses in January 2002 it was permitted to offer students 2 x 400 hours instruction over a two year period. (2) Can the Minister confirm that WA has been instructed to offer only 1 x 200 hours instruction to each student; if so, (a) why, (b) on what basis was the instruction to reduce student learning time made, and (c) is this consistent with the original contract; if not, why not. (3) Is the Minister aware that as a result of this variation WA anticipates that its enrolments will fall from 40 students per month to only 18 students between now and the end of the financial year. (4) Will the Government now allocate further funding to English language programs in the 2004 Budget; if not, why not. (5) Can the Minister give a commitment that more money will be allocated to English language programs when contracts are renewed following their expiry in December 2004; if not, why not. (6) Will the Minister reinstate WA’s funding so that it can continue to improve the English language skills of constituents in the electoral division of Throsby; if not, why not. (1) Yes. (2) WA Illawarra has not been instructed to offer only 1 x 200 hours instruction to each student. (a) The programme guidelines allow providers to offer clients between 120 and 400 hours of training in a placement depending on each individual clients training needs and a maximum of two rounds of training within a two year period from the date of the first training commencement. (b) In 2003, in order to help providers manage within the budget allocated to the programme DEST introduced a new requirement that restricted the initial allocation of training hours to clients to 200 hours. This decision was taken following analysis of Language, Literacy and Numeracy Programme (LLNP) data which showed that more than 71% of job seekers were being allocated 400 hours of training. Given that over 69% of clients who withdraw from training did so before undertaking 100 hours of training, this was considered to be an inefficient use of resources which could be better directed to new clients. (c) This arrangement is consistent with the original contract as it still allows providers to review client performance after delivery of between 190 and 200 hours (as a mid point review) and increase the number of hours to the maximum in the client’s training plan and if the client is attending well, shows motivation and needs further training, then allocate increased hours to bring their total allocation up to a maximum of 400 hours. DEST also negotiated with a number of providers to allocate additional funding to assist with the increased demand for the LLNP. However, the offer of this additional funding was contingent on providers implementing strategies to manage the increased demand within their budgets while still maximising the flow of new clients through the programme. As part of this additional funding offer the Department offered WA Illawarra an increase of $84,000 on their base funding allocation of $275,000 for English language training in 200304. On accepting this funding offer WA Illawarra proposed, and the Department agreed to,
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Dr Nelson
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:the following strategies to be implemented for all new clients assisted with the additional funding: Offering only 300 hours of training to those clients who are assessed as NRS level 1 or below; Offering only 200 hours of training to those clients who are assessed as NRS level 2 or above; and Offering second rounds of training to existing clients only in exceptional circumstances. The implementation of these strategies for the new funding has been necessary to ensure that WA Illawarra can maintain a flow of new clients and provide assistance to a greater number of jobseekers in the Illawarra region over the remaining LLNP contract period. The Department continues to work with all providers facing high demand for programme places to ensure that these providers place client interests at the forefront of the strategies they implement to ration access to programme resources. (3) According to DEST records WA Illawarra had a client intake of 40 or more in the current financial year only once in July 2003. Over the period 1 July 2002 to 30 June 2003 WA averaged an intake of just over 16 clients a month. Over the period 1 July 2003 to 30 December2003, WA averaged a client intake of 14 per month and in the first three months of 2004 this has risen to an average intake of 18 per month. Over the period 1 January 2002 to 31 December 2003 around 43% of WA clients achieved a successful outcome. (4) The 2003-04 Portfolio Budget Statements forward estimates provide for an increase of funding to the LLNP of $3.671 million in 2004-05 (for a total of $44.373 million), of $4.751 million in 200506 (for a total of $45.453 million) and $5.751 million in 2006-07 (for a total of $46.453 million) compared to the programme’s funding level in 2003-04 of $40.702 million. (5) As noted above, the 2003-04 Portfolio Budget Statements forward estimates provide for additional funding of $14.173 million for the LLNP over the period 2004-5 to 2006-07 as compared the base funding level in 2003-04. (6) In the 2002-03 financial year WA Illawarra received $300,494 in funding for English Language Training. In the 2003-04 financial year WA Illawarra has been allocated a budget of $359,000. Immigration: Integrated Humanitarian Settlement Strategy (Question No. 3234) Mr Laurie Ferguson asked the Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 2 March 2004: (1) Is it correct, as stated by officers of the Minister’s Department to the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee on 17 February 2004, that the Government has begun to trial the resettlement of unlinked offshore refugees in appropriate locations in regional Australia. (2) In which particular locations are these trials (a) currently under way, and (b) proposed. (3) How many refugees are proposed to be involved in the trials and what is the proposed timetable for their completion. (4) As part of the trials, what funding will the Commonwealth provide for (a) on-arrival settlement services, and (b) other assistance to those participating in the trials. (5) Are state and territory governments required to make a financial or other contribution to the trials: if so, what are the details.
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Hardgrave
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(1) The Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs has been settling unlinked refugees in regional areas of Australia for some time. However, the Government is trialing a new approach to the selection of appropriate locations for future settlement in regional Australia with a view to more actively linking entrants to regional employment opportunities and necessary services. (2) (a) In 2002-03, the Integrated Humanitarian Settlement Strategy (IHSS) assisted refugees to settle in Wagga Wagga and Wollongong in NSW, in Cairns, Townsville, Toowoomba, Gold Coast and the Logan/Beenleigh/ Woodridge region in Queensland, in Geelong and Shepparton in Victoria, in Launceston and the North West Coast region in Tasmania and in Alice Springs in the NT. In 200304 the IHSS also assisted refugees to settle in Coffs Harbour and Goulburn in NSW and in Mandurah in WA. (b) In 2004-05, refugees will be settled in up to four new regional locations. These locations will be determined after consultation with State and Territory governments. (3) The Government has set a notional target increase of 300-400 for 2004-05. Arrangements are intended to be ongoing, with the numbers settled in regional Australia being progressively increased taking into account the availability of employment opportunities and necessary settlement and other services. (4) (a) On arrival settlement services will continue to be provided under the Integrated Humanitarian Settlement Strategy. The existing contractual framework already provides for service delivery in regional locations. (b) Other Commonwealth funded assistance to new entrants settling in regional Australia will continue to be provided through the Adult Migrant English Program, the Community Settlement Services Scheme and mainstream service delivery programs. (5) Initiatives to expand humanitarian settlement in regional areas will be implemented in close consultation with State, Territory and local governments. State, Territory and local governments would be expected to continue to meet their responsibilities for provision of health, education, housing and other mainstream services to new entrants settling in regional locations. States and Territories will be consulted in relation to other potential avenues for support for regional settlement. Environment: Tasmanian Environment Centre (Question No. 3344) Mr Kelvin Thomson asked the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 22 March 2004: (1) In respect of the grant to the Tasmanian Environment Centre under the Grants to Voluntary Environment and Heritage Organisations (GVEHO) program, is he aware of the massive decrease in funding that the Tasmanian Environment Centre incurred in the 2003-2004 funding year. (2) Is he aware that the Tasmanian Environment Centre provides assistance and support to other environmental organisations in Tasmania, such as Birds Tasmania. (3) How does the Government justify cutting the organisation’s funding so severely. (4) What alternatives will the Government make available to organisations like the Tasmanian Environment Centre to ensure that they can continue to operate and provide the much needed resources and information that other environmental groups have come to depend upon them for. (1) Yes (2) Yes
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Dr Kemp
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(3) I decided to offer grants to regional environmental organisations at three amounts depending on the size of the organisation and geographic area covered. The Tasmanian Environment Centre was offered the maximum grant. (4) Since 1996, the Australian Government has dramatically increased the availability of funding to support environmental organisations like the Tasmanian Environment Centre through initiatives such as the Natural Heritage Trust and the Envirofund that annually provides $20 million for practical on-ground projects. Indirectly, the Government subsidises environmental organisations through taxation concession schemes such as Income Tax Exempt Charities and Deductible Gift Recipients. Environmental Deductible Gifts Recipients received over $55 million in donations in the 2002-2003 financial year and these donations, in turn, resulted in payments to taxpayers of over $22 million. Environmental organisations like the Tasmanian Environment Centre can take advantage of the very large amount of funding that the Government makes available to the environment sector through these funding programs and taxation concession schemes. Employment: Indigenous Employment Policy (Question No. 3358) Mr Albanese asked the Minister for Employment Services, upon notice, on 23 March 2004: What is the net impact on the budget of each placement under the Indigenous Employment Policy’s Wage Assistance program (taking into account savings in unemployment benefits as well as the displacement and deadweight effects). to the honourable member’s question: In the Government’s recent evaluation of the Indigenous Employment Policy estimates were derived of the impact of Wage Assistance on the ongoing employment outcomes of participants and on the hiring decisions of employers. Using these estimates it is possible to estimate the number of extra jobs Wage Assistance is responsible for annually, taking into account displacement and deadweight effects. It is not possible, however, to estimate Wage Assistance’s net impact on the budget by taking account of savings in unemployment benefits. More information about the methodology used to derive these estimates is provided in the Indigenous Employment Policy Stage Two evaluation report which is available from http://www.workplace.gov.au/Workplace/WPDisplay/0,1280,a3%253D6408%2526a0%253D0%2526a1 %253D517%2526a2%253D533,00.html. Where consideration is being given to Australia becoming a party to an international agreement, consideration is given to whether any Act, including the Migration Act, will require amendment to ensure consistency with any obligations arising from that agreement. When amendments to the Migration Act are proposed, international agreements are taken into account to ensure that the Migration Act will remain consistent with Australia’s international obligations. This was the case, for example, when the Migration Act was amended in 1999 to allow interception and boarding of vessels suspected of carrying persons without visas to Australia.

title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Hardgrave
theText: The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous AffairsImmigration: Illegal Entry (Question No. 3387) 24 March 2004: Has the Minister’s department undertaken any work to assess the cost of detecting and managing people seeking entry to Australia who have arrived on board suspect illegal entry vehicles; if so, what was the cost each financial year since 1 July 1996. able member’s question: Defence has undertaken work to assess the net additional cost of Operations RelexI and II which provide air and surface patrols across Australia’s northern approaches to deter unauthorised boat arrivals. The commitment commenced in September 2001 and Relex II is continuing. The force elements committed to the operation have varied over time in response to changed intelligence assessments, platform availability and operational tempo. The commitment has included a frigate, two patrol boats, an amphibious transport ship, P3C maritime patrol and C130 Hercules aircraft. The net additional cost of Operations RelexI and II is: FY2001-02 FY2002-03 FY2003-04 (estimated) Total $million $million $million $million 18.7 22.3 17.8 58.8 Health: Immunisation (Question No. 3397) Ms Burke asked the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 24 March 2004: (1) In respect of the announcement by the former Minister on 19 September 2003, what sum will be saved by the removal from the National Immunisation Program of the Diphtheria, Tetanus, Pertussis (whooping cough) vaccine given to children at 18 months of age. (2) Have there been changes, or are changes contemplated, to the (a) Child Care Benefit, and (b) Maternity Immunisation Allowance payment. (1) The 18 month dose of diphtheria, tetanus and pertussis (DTPa) vaccine was removed from the National Immunisation Program on the recommendation of the Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation (ATAGI). This dose was considered to be unnecessary as a result of the high level of immunity from the primary course at 2, 4, and 6 months of age. This dose also had an increased risk of local adverse events following immunisation. Removing this unnecessary dose of DTPa, will result in a saving to the National Immunisation Program. As this was the only vaccine administered at 18 months, savings are also expected in relation to payments under the Medicare Benefits Scheme and notification payments to immunisation providers. The ATAGI recommended the introduction of a dose of adult formulation diphtheria, tetanus and pertussis (dTpa) vaccine at 15-17 years, to replace the current dose of diphtheria and tetanus vaccine (ADT) vaccine provided at 15-19 years of age. The cost of replacing ADT with dTpa vaccine, taking into consideration the savings resulting from the removal of the 18 month dose of DTPa, is $5.36 million over four years.

speaker: Mr Abbott
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(2) Effective from 19 September 2003, the 18 month dose of diphtheria, tetanus and pertussis (DTPa) vaccine was removed from the immunisation requirements for Child Care Benefit and Maternity Immunisation Allowance payments. The legislation governing immunisation linkages to Child Care Benefit and Maternity Immunisation Allowance (A New Tax System (Family Assistance) Act 1999) is administered by the Department of Family and Community Services. Environment: Coastal Catchments Initiative (Question No. 3405) Mr Kelvin Thomson asked the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 25 March 2004: (1) What progress has been made in implementing the Coastal Catchments Initiative for Port Phillip Bay? (2) What is the total budget for the Coastal Catchments Initiative for the next two years? (1) My Department is negotiating with Victorian authorities the development of Water Quality Improvement Plans for Port Phillip Bay and Western Port, as well as possible interim water quality projects. (2) The total budget to date for the Coastal Catchments Initiative for the next two years is $1.82 million. This is comprised of $950,000 in 2004-05 and $870,000 in 2005-06. Additional funding will be subject to Natural Heritage Board decisions. Excise: Biodiesel (Question No. 3427) Mr Kelvin Thomson asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 31 March 2004: (1) What sum has the (a) Australian Taxation Office (ATO), and (b) Department of Treasury spent in the establishment of structures, services and resources to enable the collection of the excise on biodiesel. (2) Have there been any projections of the ongoing costs to the Government for the collection of excise on biodiesel; if so, what are the ongoing costs likely to be. (3) What sum does the Government anticipate will raise each year from biodiesel producers. (1) (a) The ATO does not break-down its costs to the level of detail sought and is therefore unable to provide information on the establishment costs for the collection of excise on biodiesel. (b) Not applicable. The ATO administers the collection of excise on biodiesel. (2) There have been no formal projections of the ongoing costs of the collection of excise on biodiesel. (3) See the revenue measure titled “Fuel tax reform” in the Treasury portfolio in Budget Paper No. 2, Budget Statement 2003-04. Defence: Sea Swap Program (Question No. 3439) Mr Melham asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 1 April 2004: (1) In respect of the Sea Swap program announced by the Minister in the press release dated 24 October 2002, (a) which United States Navy vessels have participated in the Sea Swap program,

speaker: Dr Kemp
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Costello
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(b) what was the type or class of each participating vessel, (c) at which Australian port did the transfer of each participating vessel’s crew take place, and (d) what were the dates of arrival and departure for each participating vessel. (2) Which agreement between the Australian and United States governments covers the operation of the Sea Swap program. (3) What are the Australian government’s obligations and what are the United States government’s obligations under the Sea Swap agreement. (4) Since October 2002, what costs have been incurred by the Australian Department of Defence as a consequence of the Sea Swap program. (5) What is the planned duration of the Sea Swap program. able member’s question: (1) (a) The US Fletcher on two occasions. (b) The US Fletcher is a Spruance Class Destroyer. (c) Fremantle, Western Australia. (d) US FLETCHER arrived on 19 January 2003 and departed on 26 January 2003 and arrived again on 10 December 2003 and departed on 2 January 2004. (2) There is no specific agreement that covers the operation of the Sea Swap program. The presence of the United States (US) personnel in Australia, participating in the Sea Swap program, has been conducted under the auspices of the Agreement between Australia and the United States of America concerning the Status of US Forces in Australia, and Protocol to that Agreement dated 9 May 1963. (3) Australian Defence assistance, as requested by the US, is limited to the loading and unloading of military transport aircraft and accommodation of the crews. This assistance is provided under a ‘user pays basis’ with cost recovery under existing agreements. In the absence of a specific agreement on the Sea Swap initiative, the only obligations placed on the Australian and US Governments are those legal and administrative obligations pursuant to the Status of Forces Agreement. (4) The Sea Swap program is conducted under a fee-for-service arrangement. The US Navy has been charged for all costs associated with the two Sea Swap trials conducted to date. In addition, in order to meet ongoing Australian Defence Force needs, refurbishment work was conducted on accommodation blocks at Leeuwin Barracks at a cost of $250,825. As the US Navy has used these facilities during the two Sea Swap trials, they have contributed $25,000 towards the refurbishment costs. (5) The Sea Swap program has been a trial conducted by the US Navy. The results of the program are yet to be evaluated for effectiveness by the Commander of Naval Surface Forces (US Pacific Fleet) and Commander-in-Chief (US Pacific Fleet). At this stage, there are no further US Navy ship visits planned to Australian ports as part of the Sea Swap initiative. Education, Science and Training: Travel Expenses (Question No. 3462) Mr Quick asked the Minister for Education, Science and Training, upon notice, 1 April 2004: (1) For the financial year (a) 2000/2001, and (b) 2002/2003, what sum was spent by the Minister’s department on domestic and overseas air travel.

(5) For the financial year (a) 2000/2001, and (b) 2002/2003, what sum was spent by the Minister’s department on economy class travel on (i) domestic routes, and (ii) overseas routes. (6) For the financial year (a) 2000/2001, and (b) 2002/2003, what proportion of the expenditure on air travel by the Minister’s department was on the domestic routes (i) Sydney to Canberra, (ii) Melbourne to Canberra, (iii) Sydney to Melbourne, (iv) Sydney to Brisbane, (v) Melbourne to Hobart or Launceston, and (vi) Sydney to Perth.
